What canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Mark Kozelek do with a song? After more than 20 years fronting legendary sad sacks Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon, Kozelek, through his stripped-down, honest songwriting approach, has demonstrated an uncanny ability to cut straight through the bullshit and get at the core of whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s real.
But while KozelekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s original material has earned him a reputation as one of the most unflinching songwriters of his generation, his ability to unlock the sentimental riches in other peopleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work further cements his ability to find the heart of a song. Like Rats, a diverse collection of 13 covers from various artists spanning numerous genres, puts KozelekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s knack for musical reinvention to a vexing test, but in the end he passes with flying colors.

Whether heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s tackling punk-reggae (Bad BrainsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) or just punk (The DescendentsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬Å“Silly GirlÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), metal (DanzigÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThirteenÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) or pop music mainstays (Sonny and CherÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“I Got You BabeÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), Kozelek leaves little to no trace of the songsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ origins, wiping the slate clean and filtering the music through his own staggeringly forlorn muse. Bruno MarsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬Å“Young GirlsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is stripped of its stomping drums, soaring vocals, and pop sass and left with KozelekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s low mumble (Ã¢â‚¬Å“You young, wild girls, you make a mess of me / You young, wild girls will be the death of meÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) and sullen guitar, while The Misfits Ã¢â‚¬Å“Green HellÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is reduced to a hollow, moving shell of its manic, original version. Even the half-crazed cock rock of Ted Nugent (Ã¢â‚¬Å“Free-For-AllÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t invincible to KozelekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s human touch.

With weary vocals, trembling guitar, and a disposition to match, Kozelek makes sense of a slate of songs that otherwise share little if any common ground. Sometimes less is more, and Like Rats offers up considerable proof.
